@scottthewaterwarrior Classes on fiscal responsibility would be a great thing to have. Part of the problem lies in we are in a "I want it now" world, where people don't think about the future, only currently in what they want, not necessarily need. And yes, that falls into the fiscally responsible ideology.

@Dan R I don't see a whole lot of people living paycheck to paycheck in $30,000 vehicles. I mean, I'm pretty sure transit busses cost a lot more than that...

I agree there are some people who just do not budget correctly, and I honestly do not know how large a percentage of paycheck to paycheck workers that is.
However, assuming it is a significant number, maybe that is a sign that there is something wrong with our education system? Classes on fiscal responsibility should be required in all high schools, and yet many schools in poor areas can't even afford to properly teach academic subjects, forget having classes on life skills. School funding needs to be disconnected from local taxes, funding schools per child is the only way to give all children an equal opportunity. Course there are plenty of other factors that aren't equal and effect how successful a child will be, but fairly funding the public school systems is one that the government can directly impact.
